newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico sees '97 OJ concentrate output down - SNIM.
newsitem.headline: Mexico sees '97 OJ concentrate output down - SNIM.

text.p: Mexico will produce around 48,000 tonnes of orange juice concentrate in 1997, down from the 50,000 tonne output in 1996, National Market Information Service (SNIM) said Tuesday.

SNIM, an arm of the Trade Ministry, said in a document that the fall in orange juice concentrade is expected because national fresh orange demand is seen climbing with the country's economic recovery.

"It will limit the availability of oranges to be made into concentrate," SNIM said. Mexico suffered a massive recession following the bungled December 1994 devaluation, crushing people's purchasing power.
SNIM said the majority of the orange juice concentrate production in Mexico will go to the export market given Mexico's onw consumption of concentrate remains low.
"Exports of orange juice concentrate in the 1997 calendar year are estimated to be around 46,000 tonnes, slight down from 1996," SNIM said, without giving export figures for last year.

Under the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mexico has the right to export 40 million equivalent gallons of concentrate to the the United States with a tariff of 4.625 U.S. cents per gallon up to the year 2005, SNIM said. ((--Chris Aspin, Mexico City newsroom +525 728-9530))
